Some old bioses:  
I have lexar usb, it is modified by flashboot.ru so it is seen like FDD + HDD.  

And this old bios i found is so stupid that it sees only FDD part.  
SO ok i loaded from this part PLOP and tried to boot HDD part but this wont go.  

Is there some other boot manager with own usb drivers ?  
Or do you have other idea ? (1.44mb space on fdd)  
GRUB also is not seeing HDD part, bios does not load it, only loads first thing he can see and nothing more.

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content:
I have a car and it won't start - can you fix it? My point is it would help if we had some **details** ! USB is made by lexar - but what model, what size? Won't boot - boot to what OS won't it boot? It only loads first thing it can see - do you mean the BIOS will not boot at all from the USB pen - does the USB pen LED flash at all? What BIOS options do you have? Do you have any USB pens that do work or any more that don't? If so, what make, model and size are they?
Some BIOSes will not boot from a USB pen if larger than 512MB. Some BIOSes may boot if you use a partition table with two partitions (try RMPrepUSB with HDD option).

No, there in no other bootmanager with USB stack AFAIK, but my guess is that the issue is connected to the way the stick has been "set" with it's Manufacturer's tool.  

What you can ***try*** is using the double (actually triple) makbootfat MBR/PBR, but I doubt that it can work since what is missing is actually the "device" ![:ph34r:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/scared9.gif)  

Some info and a helper are here:

forumNotes.author: Icecube
forumNotes.content:
> Is there some other boot manager with own usb drivers ?
**grub2** has its own USB drivers:  
> Many BIOSs do not support booting from USB, with this option you can use Super GRUB2 Disk (booted from a floppy, CD, or other media that your BIOS does support booting from) to boot an operating system from a USB drive despite your BIOSs limitation, using GRUB2's native USB drivers. This option will only allow you boot Free Operating Systems like GNU/Linux or FreeBSD, chainloading will not work with this option and so it cannot be used to boot Windows from a USB drive. This option, as stated, is still experimental.
[http://www.supergrub...experimental.2A](http://www.supergrubdisk.org/wiki/SuperGRUB2Disk#Enable_GRUB2.27s_USB_support_.2Aexperimental.2A "External link")  
[http://www.boot-land...mp;#entry109124](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=12395&pid=109124&st=10&#entry109124 "External link")  

Maybe **burg** (based on grub2) allows you to boot non-free Operating Systems too from USB:  
[http://www.boot-land...showtopic=12474](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=12474 "External link")
